div.head:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE LAUNCESTON
EXAMINER.

div.p:
Sir,—In your paper of the 19th instant, you
have favored us with a review of the Tasmanian
Journal, No. 5, vol. 3, and I regret to observe
that the transalationtranslation you have given of Humboldt’s
letter is very incorrect. It has been well said,
“everything suffers by translation but a bishop,”
and your ingenious traducteur has so contrived to
trans-mogrify the letter in question, that I fear the
venerable author himself would not recognise it.
It reminds one of the exclamation made by a
person on seeing the portrait of his friend—“it is
so like you would not know it!”—I therefore send
you a more correct, and, I hope, more intelligible
version.—I am, Sir,

A Member of the Tasmanian Society.
Launceston.

“How rejoiced I am to learn, my excellent
friend, that you are about to penetrate those beau-
tiful vallies of the Himalayah, and even beyond,
towards Ladak and the plateaux of Thibet; the
mean elevation of which, apart from that of the
peaks which rise from the table-land itself, is an
object worthy of research! How I appreciate that
noble ardor which induces you to undertake ano-
ther hazardous expedition, after having been in
that to the South Pole, which was so gloriously
conducted. Your agreeable letter of the 5th
September, found me rather indisposed. I have
been living at the park Sans Souci during the
absence of the King, and the excessive cold has
compelled me to return to town. My depar-
ture for Paris has been deferred, and I have
thus corrected here the last sheets of the second
volume of Cosmos, which will shortly appear. I
expect the King and Queen will return to-morrow,
and I shall be able to set out about the 4th Oct.,
so as to pass two or three months in Paris. I
begin to console myself for the injustice they did
you in not giving you the chair of Edinburgh;
for, from the extent and variety of information
which you possess, you are called upon to render
eminent services not only to the geography of
plants, but also to all branches of meteorology, as
well as to geology. You have the advantage that
your views are enlarged, and you have a taste (a
feeling) for exactness.

“I congratulate the ‘Board of Admiralty’ and
the ‘Commissioners of Woods and Forests,’ in
the name of that department of the physical sci-
ences to which all my life has been devoted, upon
the choice which they have made, in extending to
you their patronage, and of which you are so
worthy, —by your acquirements,— by the vivacity
and ardor of your character,—and by the constancy
of a devotedness so disinterested! I look back with
pleasure to the remembrance of those conversa-
tions, to me so instructive, during the time I lived
in the same house with you in Paris: I took
notes of them almost from your dictation, and it
gives me pleasure to find them among my papers;
—happy advantage of old age which has so few!
Your excellent father has undertaken the publi-
cation of my Cryptogamic plants of the Cordil-
leras; and here is his son, whom I have the
pleasure of calling my young friend, has seen
the eruptions of Mount Erebus, and is about to see
that which has been the dream of my life, now
near its close.

“Do not forget, my dear friend, to write to me
at Paris, before setting out on this magnificent
expedition. I am delighted with your (paper on
the) Gallipagos, but would be very glad if you
would draw up for my information a few geogra-
phic notes, merely specifying such European or
American Phanerogamic plants, as are without
doubt indigenous to the southern hemisphere,
not American. Tell me also something about your
Cælebogyne ilicifolia, which Jussieu places among
the Euphorbiaceæ. Is the idea of fertile seeds
without stamina still entertained?—what do you
think of it?

“I need scarcely call your attention to specific
objects, acquainted as you are with the problems
which they involve.

“The altitudes at which certain families of
plants cease.

“Do the characteristics of the Siberian Flora
extend so far into Cashmere and Ladak, as has
been supposed?

“To what altitude are fish found in the lakes?
Compare their species and determine their affini-
nitiesaffini-
ties.

“Be particularly attentive to the temperature
of the soil at different altitudes.

“As a test for this purpose, compare the
temperature of the soil within the tropics at from
18 inches, to 2 feet below the surface, (Boussin-
gault) with the depth of 20 or 30 feet (and repeat
these observations as you advance) northwards.

“Clear up the problem about the height of per-
petual snow on the southern and northern slopes
of the Himalayah, bearing in mind the data which
I have brought together in the 3rd vol. of my work
on Central Asia.

“I cannot believe in the uniformity and un-
broken continuity of the Gneiss, Mica schists, or
Silurian formations of the Himalayah.

“Observe particularly the Porphyritic forma-
tions—the Greenstone, the Amygdaloids(?), the
Basalts(?) of the chain.

“If you are fortunate enough to cross the grand
Cordillera of Kouenlun in order to reach Yark-
and, in ascending towards the sources of the
Cajouh, a tributary of the Indus, observe atten-
tively the lowest point of elevation of the plain
which sends its waters to the east, by the (River)
Tarem to Lake Lop.

“It would be most desirable to determine the
height of the plain to the east of Yarkand by
barometric observation, or, if you can manage it,
by the boiling point of water.

“The horary variations of the barometer on the
plateaux, and on the Himalayah itself.

“Psychrometric observations, so as to compare
their results with the excessive dryness which I
experienced on the Steppes of Siberia.

“The temperature of caverns at their further
extremities.
“Do insects live at a less height than plants?

“I must cease, lest I tire you with what you
know better than myself.

“Accept the renewed expression of my deep
and affectionate esteem both for yourself, my
excellent friend, and your respected father, Sir
William.

“My compliments to your talented friend, Mr.
Darwin, all whose works delight me.

“I have no time to read over my scrawl. I
am going to see how many Nos. of your beautiful
Flora I possess.”

[We are not displeased to have another transla-
tion of this interesting communication; but the
“Member,” or the Editor of the Tasmanian Jour-
nal, ought to have saved us from giving two
versions by publishing it in English.—Ed. L. E.]
